subsection.title: Summation Notation
subsection.p: There is a convenient notation for representing a series. For example, consider the sum of the first fifteen terms of the sequence 4, 7, 10, \cdots, 3n+1, \cdots To find the terms of the series we replace n in the general term 3n+1 by the numbers 1 through 15. So, instead of writing out all the terms, we might express the sum as \text{The sum, as}~ n~ \text{runs from 1 to 15, of}~ 3n+1 We use the Greek letter \Sigma (called "sigma") to stand for "the sum," and we show the first and last values of n below and above the summation symbol \Sigma, like this: \sum_{n=1}^{15} 3n+1 Writing such an expression is sometimes called "using sigma notation." The letter n is called the index of summation; it is like a variable because it represents numerical values.

note.p: Any letter can be used for the index of summation; i,~j, and k are other common choices. Of course, the letter used for the index of summation does not affect the sum.

subsection.p: The expanded form of a series written in sigma notation is obtained by writing out all the terms of the series. For example, \sum_{m=4}^{8} \dfrac{3}{m} = \dfrac{3}{4} + \dfrac{3}{5} + \dfrac{3}{6} + \dfrac{3}{7} + \dfrac{3}{8}

note.p: Notice that the series above has five terms, which is one more than the difference of the upper and lower limits of summation, 8 - 4.

subsection.p: Recall that the general term of an arithmetic series is a linear function of the index, and the general term of a geometric series is an exponential function. If we recognize a given series as one of these two types, we can use the formulas developed in the last section to evaluate the sum.

subsection.title: Infinite Series
subsection.p: A series with infinitely many terms is called an infinite series. Is it possible to add infinitely many terms and arrive at a finite sum? In some cases, if the terms added are small enough, the answer is yes.

note.p: Will the partial sums ever be greater than 1? No, because each new term a_n added is half the difference between S_n and 1.

subsection.p:
We can make this conjecture more plausible by examining the formula for the n^{\text{th}} partial sum of a geometric series,
S_n\amp = \dfrac{a_{n+1} - a_1}{r-1} \amp = \dfrac{ar^n - a}{r-1} = \dfrac{a - ar^n}{1-r} \amp\amp (r \not= 1)
Look at the second term of the numerator, ar^n. This term is the only part of the formula that depends on n. What happens to ar^n as n increases? Consider two examples:

li.p: If r = \dfrac{1}{2}, then r^2 = \left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^2 = \dfrac{1}{4},\qquad r^3 = \left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^3 = \dfrac{1}{8},\qquad r^4 = \left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^4 = \dfrac{1}{16}, and so on, with \left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^n becoming smaller and smaller for larger values of n. Each time we multiply by another factor of r=\dfrac{1}{2}, the product gets smaller, because \dfrac{1}{2} \lt 1.

On the other hand, if r \gt 1, multiplying by r makes the product larger. If r = \dfrac{3}{2} for example, then r^2 = \left(\dfrac{3}{2}\right)^2 = \dfrac{9}{4},\qquad r^3 = \left(\dfrac{3}{2}\right)^3 = \dfrac{27}{8},\qquad r^4 = \left(\dfrac{3}{2}\right)^4 = \dfrac{81}{16}, and so on. In this case the powers of r are increasing.

subsection.p: In general, we have the following result.

ol.li: If 0 \lt \abs{r} \lt 1, then r^n gets closer to zero as n increases.
If \abs{r} \gt 1, then r^n does not approach a finite number as n increases.

subsection.p: Now let's return to the formula for S_n and write it in the form S_n = \dfrac{a}{1-r} (1-r^n) where we have factored a from the numerator. There are two cases to consider. If \abs{r} \lt 1, then r^n approaches 0, and the factor 1-r^n gets closer and closer to 1 as n grows larger. Consequently, if we compute S_n for larger and larger values of n, the sum approaches the value \dfrac{a}{1-r} This analysis motivates us to define the sum of an infinite geometric series as follows.

assemblage.title: Sum of an Infinite Geometric Series
assemblage.p: The sum of an infinite geometric series ~~\displaystyle{\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} ar^{k-1}}~~ is S_{\infty} = \dfrac{a}{1-r}~~~~~~\text{if}~~~~-1 \lt r \lt 1

subsection.p: In the second case, if \abs{r} \gt 1, as in the infinite series 3 + 6 + 12 + \cdots where r = 2, the terms become larger as n increases, and the sum of the series is not a finite number. In this case the series does not have a sum.

subsection.title: Repeating Decimals
subsection.p: An interesting application of geometric series involves repeating decimals. Recall that the decimal representation of a rational number either terminates, as does 0.75, or repeats a pattern of digits. For example, you probably recognize 0.333\overline{3} as the decimal representation of \dfrac{1}{3}. It is easy to find the decimal form of a fraction: we just divide the denominator into the numerator. Is there a way to find the fractional form of a repeating decimal?

Consider the repeating decimal 0.2121\overline{21} We can write this number as an infinite geometric series: 0.21 + 0.0021 + 0.000021 + \cdots The first term of this series is 0.21, or \dfrac{21}{100}, and its common ratio is r=0.01, or \dfrac{1}{100}. Because \abs{r} \lt 1, the series has a sum given by \begin{aligned}[t] S_{\infty}\amp = \dfrac{a}{1-r} = \dfrac{\dfrac{21}{100}}{1-\dfrac{1}{100}}\\ \amp = \dfrac{\dfrac{21}{100}}{\dfrac{99}{100}} = \dfrac{21}{99} = \dfrac{7}{33}\\ \end{aligned} Thus, the decimal number 0.2121\overline{21} is equal to the fraction \dfrac{7}{33}.

statement.p: Find a common fraction equivalent to 0.3\overline{7}.

solution.p:
The decimal can be written as 0.3 + 0.0\overline{7}. We will find a fraction equivalent to the repeating decimal 0.0\overline{7} and add that to 0.3, or \dfrac{3}{10}. We write 0.0\overline{7} as a series: 0.0\overline{7} = \dfrac{7}{100} + \dfrac{7}{1000} + \dfrac{7}{10,000} + \cdots This is an infinite geometric series with first term \dfrac{7}{100} and common ratio \dfrac{1}{10}. The sum of the series is given by \begin{aligned}[t] S_{\infty}\amp = \dfrac{a}{1-r} = \dfrac{\dfrac{7}{100}}{1-\dfrac{1}{10}}\\ \amp = \dfrac{\dfrac{7}{100}}{\dfrac{9}{10}} = \dfrac{7}{100} \cdot \dfrac{9}{10} = \dfrac{7}{90}\\ \end{aligned}
Finally, we add \dfrac{7}{90} and \dfrac{3}{10} to find 0.3\overline{7} = \dfrac{3}{10}+\dfrac{7}{90} = \dfrac{34}{90}
